text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen the 
holiday season is coming up so we are going to

do some Christmas baking or New Year baking or 
whatever it is you celebrate they're basically

festive little cookies that are great as 
gifts we are making Singapore cookies or

in Thai cookies syncopal now apparently it's 
not a thing in Singapore they have a similar

thing called cashew cookies I don't know why we 
call them Singapore cookies but basically they

are little shortbread cookies with the cashew 
on top with an egg yolk glaze and today we are

going to make ours with black sesame flavor they 
are so so good and you can make them in advance

and package them and send them to someone far 
away Oh perfect let's get started first order of

business the black sesame seeds now what you want 
to do is toast these and to do that put them in a

saute pan dry with no oil or anything and just 
keep toasting them over medium heat until they

start popping and smoking now because they're 
black it's very hard to tell if they're toasted

or burnt or under toasted so what I go by is 
once they start popping a lot let them pop for

about 10-15 seconds and turn it off look at them 
really closely and some of the black coating will

start to split and you can see the white seed 
underneath the slit and if that white seed has

browned then you know that they're toasted you do 
not want to get lazy and skip this part I know we

all try to shortcut recipes all the time this is 
not a place to do it if you are in a rush you can

buy sesame seeds already toasted usually in the 
Japanese aisle they sell black summate sesame

seeds already toasted if you don't toast these 
you will not get that iconic black sesame flavor

also important that you don't under toast it if 
you under toast it again the full flavor won't

come out okay we're going to grind it up into a 
powder you can also make white ones with white

sesame seeds if you don't like sesame at all you 
can just do ground toasted cashews here goes and

I'm pulsing and shaking it because I do not want 
this to to sesame butter there we go and I know

mine was nicely toasted because I can see a tint 
of brown once I've ground it up now we're going to

just mix up our dry ingredients so I've got some 
all-purpose flour here now my little secret is

I'm going to mix in some tapioca starch tapioca 
starch is going to reduce the total amount of

gluten in this recipe and it's going to make the 
cookies tender and crumbly and it gives almost a

creaminess after you start chewing a little bit of 
salt go in with the black sesame give that a whisk

you want this well mixed before you mix it in with 
the wet ingredients I have got my stand mixer here

which I love but you don't need this you can just 
use the hand mixer or you can even do this by hand

if you want it'll take a little more time but it's 
not a big deal I'm going to beat in some unsalted

butter which has been softened so I pulled this 
out last night beat it a couple of times just to

break up the butter that's it on Lois feet again 
I do not want to whisk air into it so icing sugar

or powdered sugar hmm this is what I always inhale 
sugar and suddenly it's sweetened my mouth neutral

flavored oil anything will do that's neutral 
flavored and now we're just going to mix it

until it's combined on the lowest speed scrape 
the side one time to get everybody in the pool

I'm going to add my dry ingredients 
see this is almost done only about

half of it I just find it mixes more 
easily if I do it half at a time

then you go in with the other half and I find 
you kick up less flour in the air this way too

okay I'm going to give it a quick 
scrape just to make sure nothing

is left unattended at the very bottom so 
get to the very bottom one last stretch

that's it it's done now it's going to look crumbly 
that's what you want it'll come together in the

end but at this point what you're looking for 
is that it's a homogeneous texture that you

don't have any lumps of butter or any lumps of 
dry flour and all this will come into a dough

in no time and now you're just going to quickly 
knead this together into a ball and you're not

really kneading it like bread you're just trying 
to bring it together into a dough so it's not

crumbly anymore and see it sticking together 
quite nicely if at this point you're kneading

it and it's cracked it's not holding together well 
it's cracking everywhere put it back in the mixer

add a like a teaspoon of oil at a time to try to 
moisten it a little bit more okay so now that it's

sort of a dough hey I've got little cracks that's 
okay the problem I was talking about is if it's

just kind of everywhere now we're going to flatten 
it into a sheet about a centimeter thick so these

cookies are quite thick and which is why they're 
so cute because they're tiny little cookie but

they're thick sort of like this little cube so I'm 
going to use my rolling pin but I find it's easier

to get it started by just sort of hitting it don't 
worry about the cracks that form it will resolve

itself out roll it out a little more see because 
this dough is quite moist it tends to stick so

them back the bashing works well so one centimetre 
and now I'm going to try to salvage the edges and

you will not overwork this dough there's too much 
butter in here and the tapioca starch helps as

well sit a little thick yeah it's a little thick 
I'm gonna yeah that's good okay so once you've got

it down to the right thickness just give it a roll 
to smooth out the surface because you want this to

be a flat surface and now it's cookie cutter time 
for cookie syncopal you want little little cookie

cutters okay they're supposed to be bite-sized 
cute little things I got these at the Japanese

dollar store and there they were actually labeled 
veg bowl cutters avoid cookie cutters that have a

lot of small thin corners those are going 
to burn quickly and also this is a pretty

crumbly dough so those edges will tend to break 
off more easily so something that's round ish

if you're happy with the amount of flowers 
that you have and you're just getting lazy

towards the end because trust me this is going 
to feel like oh my god this is lasting forever

I keep having more and more dough I just cut them 
into squares and those are the ones that I'll eat

myself and those ones that I'm gonna give it to 
other people because at some point you're just

like alright that's enough nothing wrong with 
squared cookies these cookies are gonna get

little cashews garnished on top but the thing is 
you only need a half of a cashew and they almost

never sell cashews already split and these are 
raw but if all you can find is roasted they will

work as well what you do is you hold a paring 
knife you grip the blade so it's firm if there's

a little sometimes there's a little button right 
here remove the little button it's like a little

nut and wedge the knife into the middle of the 
cashew and then just rock the knife forward and

backward and eventually it'll get inside and some 
cashews will split right now but some are sort of

more tightly bound together so you have to go a 
little further before you can cleanly split them

off now we're going to give these cookies you can 
couple the iconic glaze and it's simply just egg

yolk so I've got an egg yolk here and a pastry 
brush and then brush the top just like that and

now I'm going to put the cashews on and it's like 
a little smiley face I've seen one where they use

a little rubber rubber ducky cookie cutter and 
then the cashews are like wings that was really

cute too these are raw right now but by the time 
they come out they will be perfectly roasted if

you already have roasted cashews when they come 
out they'll still be roasted they're not going to

be burnt so don't worry about that just one more 
glaze quickly over the cashews now if you're lazy

and you needed a shortcut you could just put the 
cashews on and then put the glaze on I just find

it that way because of this little corner here 
it's hard to get the glaze evenly on the cookie

so I like to do a brush on the cookie first when 
it's flat and then do one more brush at the end

all right up again check these out bears I look at 
the bottom and it should just have a light golden

color on it if you got no color at all the flavor 
isn't as intense I like it a little bit toasty so

I'm going to show you the white sesame ones that I 
made exact same recipe except I use toasted white

sesame instead of black so same idea a little bit 
of a light brown color on these I actually like

to make too cuz then they look really cute side 
by side black and white they're almost too - to

eat I'm surprised how good these are every time I 
eat them because they look so you know they look

like regular simple shortbread cookies but but 
the flavor of the toasted black sesame really

brings them to another level and suddenly 
there's something exotic that you don't run

into very often nice and brittle because of that 
tapioca as you chew it just becomes a little bit

creamy so for the holiday season pack these up 
for your friends or bake them for yourself but

I have to warn you these are addictive when I 
was testing for this recipe I had someone here

on in the house and they did not last long to us 
it was terrible in a good way so I hope you give

this a try the recipe as always is on hot pie 
kitchen calm when you make it send me a photo

Facebook Twitter or Instagram I'd love to see if 
you make them into different shapes and oh send

me the photos and I'll include them into my new 
sweater if you haven't subscribed to the YouTube

channel you can do so right here and I will 
see you next time for your next delicious tiny
